Feature / Task: Fix PaceTrendChart formatting bug
User Story / Description: Pace displays '8:352' instead of '8:05' — uses wrong variable in padStart()
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Broken formatting destroys trust in data accuracy
Competitors Who Do This: All competitors display pace correctly

Feature / Task: Consolidate formatPace() — one function everywhere
User Story / Description: 4+ duplicate implementations with inconsistent behavior
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Inconsistent pace display = inconsistent user experience
Competitors Who Do This: N/A — internal code quality

Feature / Task: Consolidate VDOT calculation — one method everywhere
User Story / Description: 3 different VDOT implementations produce different results for same input
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): VDOT is the core fitness metric — must be trustworthy and consistent
Competitors Who Do This: V.O2, Runalyze, COROS all have single canonical VDOT
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Single source of truth for fitness estimation

Feature / Task: Fix schema mismatches (SQLite vs Postgres)
User Story / Description: Strava IDs can exceed 32-bit, elevation loses precision, coachContext table missing in prod
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Data loss in production is catastrophic
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Fix elevation profile — show actual ups and downs
User Story / Description: Shows only cumulative gain, not terrain profile
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Elevation profile is a basic expectation on every workout detail page
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Garmin, every tool shows proper elevation profile

Feature / Task: Fix EnhancedSplits — pace format + header naming
User Story / Description: Pace shows '8:3.2762', header says 'Mile Splits' but data is watch laps
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Splits are a core workout review feature
Competitors Who Do This: All competitors

Feature / Task: Fix runs-by-day chart invisible color
User Story / Description: White on white background makes one data series invisible
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Chart is unusable
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Fix goal calculator
User Story / Description: Totally broken per user feedback
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Goal setting is a core motivational feature
Competitors Who Do This: Garmin, COROS, Strava all have goal tracking

Feature / Task: Unified color system for all charts
User Story / Description: 4 different color approaches across charts — inconsistent visual language
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Consistent design builds professional credibility and trust
Competitors Who Do This: Intervals.icu, Strava have consistent chart styling
Notes: Migrate all to workout-colors.ts or CSS variables

Feature / Task: Standardize time range selectors on all charts
User Story / Description: Some charts have 1M/3M/6M/1Y, some are fixed at 12 weeks, some show all history
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Inconsistent controls confuse users about what time period they're viewing
Competitors Who Do This: Intervals.icu has consistent selectors everywhere

Feature / Task: Chart design system — shared wrapper component
User Story / Description: Create reusable chart component with loading states, empty states, responsive sizing, consistent tooltips
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Design system reduces dev time for all future charts and ensures consistency
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks chart library approach

Feature / Task: VDOT display consistency — clarify Training vs Estimated
User Story / Description: 3 different VDOT storage locations, 3 different confidence calculations
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Users need to trust the core fitness number — confusion kills trust
Competitors Who Do This: V.O2 has one canonical VDOT per athlete

Feature / Task: Remove/gate 11 test/debug pages from production
User Story / Description: Test pages accessible in production — unprofessional
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Consolidate 10 Strava pages → 3
User Story / Description: 10 Strava-related pages confuse routing and maintenance
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Delete dead code (5 files, 0 imports)
User Story / Description: StravaManualConnect, strava-manual, strava-debug, /welcome, /race-predictor
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Fix hardcoded profileId: 1 in coach-tools.ts
User Story / Description: CTL/ATL/TSB hardcoded to 0 — breaks multi-user support
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Remove demo seed fallback secret
User Story / Description: Falls back to 'demo-seed-2024' if env var missing — security risk
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Fix silent profile ID failures — add null checks + error messages
User Story / Description: Functions fail silently when profile ID is null
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Implement BestEfforts.tsx stub functions (4 functions)
User Story / Description: getBestEfforts, getBestMileSplits, getPaceCurve, getWorkoutRanking all unimplemented
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Best efforts / pace curve is a flagship analytics feature
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Garmin, Runalyze all show best efforts
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Foundation for VDOT and PR tracking

Feature / Task: Implement import page activity processing
User Story / Description: Upload page exists but doesn't actually process or save activities
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): File import is critical for users migrating from other platforms
Competitors Who Do This: Runalyze, Intervals.icu, Golden Cheetah all support file import

Feature / Task: Create missing database tables (3 tables)
User Story / Description: conversationSummaries, responseCache, workoutTemplates — all blocking features
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): These tables are prerequisites for coach memory, caching, and workout library
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Encrypt stored API tokens
User Story / Description: Strava & Intervals.icu tokens stored as plaintext despite schema claiming encryption
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Token exposure is a serious security and privacy risk
Competitors Who Do This: All production apps encrypt tokens

Feature / Task: Link planned races to race results
User Story / Description: races and raceResults tables are completely separate — no lifecycle
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): The plan→train→race→analyze loop is THE core user journey
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks, Garmin, COROS all have race lifecycle
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI coach can reference entire race history for context

Feature / Task: Race history timeline — visual hero view
User Story / Description: Race results buried in collapsible section instead of being the centerpiece
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Race history is a runner's 'career page' — should feel proud and prominent
Competitors Who Do This: Runalyze, Strava PR page, SmashRun badges

Feature / Task: PR tracking by standard distance (5K/10K/HM/M)
User Story / Description: No unified PR tracking or progression visualization
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): PRs are the most emotionally significant data points for runners
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Garmin, Runalyze all track PRs

Feature / Task: Race calendar view with countdown + training phases
User Story / Description: No unified view showing upcoming races, past results, and training blocks
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Visualizing the training cycle creates accountability and excitement
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks ATP view, Intervals.icu season planner

Feature / Task: Training plan ↔ race wiring — generate plan from race page
User Story / Description: Schema exists but no UI for plan generation, viewing, or adherence tracking
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Plan adherence is the #1 predictor of race success
Competitors Who Do This: Runna, TrainingPeaks, V.O2, TrainAsONE
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI generates AND adapts the plan

Feature / Task: Bulk edit / retroactive race linking
User Story / Description: No way to clean up historical data by linking old results to workouts
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Data quality compounds — clean history enables better predictions
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks bulk edit

Feature / Task: Post-run check-in flow — standard questions after sync
User Story / Description: After a run syncs, coach should proactively ask: How did it feel? Analyze with full context. Suggest follow-up.
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): The post-run moment is when runners are most engaged and receptive to coaching
Competitors Who Do This: Runna has post-run AI insights; Garmin has morning report
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: NOBODY does contextual post-run coaching with full data awareness — this is Dreamy's killer feature

Feature / Task: 'Why did today feel hard?' auto-analysis engine
User Story / Description: Cross-reference sleep, weather, TSB, previous load, time of day, pace vs history, shoes
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Understanding WHY a run felt hard is the most common coaching question
Competitors Who Do This: WHOOP Journal correlates variables; nobody does this for individual runs
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Multi-factor explanation with ranked contributing factors — unique in the market

Feature / Task: Explain workout difficulty — coach tool
User Story / Description: Coach tool that analyzes all factors contributing to perceived effort
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Makes AI coaching responses data-driven rather than generic
Competitors Who Do This: No tool has this as a structured analysis

Feature / Task: Adaptive plan — weekly re-evaluation + diff view
User Story / Description: Plan generated once and never changes. Should re-evaluate weekly based on execution and fatigue.
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Static plans fail when life happens — adaptation is the core promise of AI coaching
Competitors Who Do This: TrainAsONE, 2PEAK, TrainerRoad Adaptive Training, Athletica.ai
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Show the user WHAT changed and WHY (transparency > black box)

Feature / Task: Coach action approval workflow — show diff, confirm/reject
User Story / Description: When coach suggests changes, user should see what's changing and approve
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Agency over your training plan builds trust and engagement
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks coach prescription workflow
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI suggests, human approves — best of both worlds

Feature / Task: Progressive context collection — profile completion %
User Story / Description: Smart prompts for missing information, adaptive context requests
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Better context = better coaching = better outcomes
Competitors Who Do This: No competitor does progressive profiling well
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Makes the AI smarter over time

Feature / Task: Import cadence data from Strava
User Story / Description: average_cadence available but not requested — needed for form analysis
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Cadence + pace → stride length, a key biomechanics metric
Competitors Who Do This: Garmin, Runalyze, Intervals.icu all show cadence

Feature / Task: Import gear_id from Strava activities
User Story / Description: Every activity has gear_id linking to shoes — not currently extracted
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Foundation for entire shoe intelligence feature set in Phase 3
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Runalyze, SportTracks track gear

Feature / Task: Import best_efforts from Strava
User Story / Description: Verified PRs (400m→marathon) with pauses excluded — gold for VDOT
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Best efforts are the highest-quality input for fitness estimation
Competitors Who Do This: Strava shows these natively

Feature / Task: Import activity zones from Strava
User Story / Description: GET /activities/{id}/zones gives HR zone breakdown for free
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Validate our zone calculations or use Strava's as baseline
Competitors Who Do This: Strava subscriber feature

Feature / Task: Implement Strava webhook for real-time sync
User Story / Description: Real-time activity notification instead of manual polling. Critical for rate limits.
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Polling doesn't scale; webhook is required for production-grade Strava integration
Competitors Who Do This: All serious Strava integrations use webhooks

Feature / Task: Import Strava athlete stats (YTD/all-time)
User Story / Description: Free data: YTD totals, all-time totals, biggest efforts
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Quick wins for profile richness without extra API calls
Competitors Who Do This: Strava shows this on athlete profile

Feature / Task: Import Strava athlete zones (HR + power)
User Story / Description: Respect user's pre-configured zones from Strava
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Users who've set custom zones in Strava expect them to be honored
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks respects Strava zones

Feature / Task: Complete lap sync for remaining 392 workouts
User Story / Description: Rate limited at last attempt — just needs retry
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Complete data = better analytics
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Test and fix production OAuth callback
User Story / Description: Middleware fix applied but untested in production
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): OAuth is the front door — if it's broken, nobody gets in
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Manual run entry UX — sliders + smart defaults
User Story / Description: Replace input fields with sliders, defaults from recent workouts
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Frictionless manual entry for treadmill runs and GPS-free workouts
Competitors Who Do This: Nike Run Club has clean manual entry

Feature / Task: Restore cheaper model usage tips popup
User Story / Description: Pop-up tips for cheaper model usage disappeared from coach page
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Users need to manage AI costs
Competitors Who Do This: N/A

Feature / Task: Import grade_smooth streams + calculate GAP
User Story / Description: Grade Adjusted Pace makes hilly and flat runs directly comparable
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): GAP is the single most important normalization for training analysis
Competitors Who Do This: Strava shows GAP; Garmin shows it; Sauce adds it
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: GAP-based training load is genuinely novel for a coaching app

Feature / Task: Import Strava best_efforts for high-confidence VDOT
User Story / Description: Verified PRs (pauses excluded) as VDOT input signals — fixes the VDOT 120.8 bug class
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Garbage in, garbage out — best_efforts are the cleanest performance data available
Competitors Who Do This: Runalyze uses race results for VDOT; V.O2 uses race entries
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Multi-signal VDOT with confidence weighting is unique

Feature / Task: Import segment efforts — PR tracking on specific segments
User Story / Description: Verified, pause-free data with achievement rankings
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Segment PRs show improvement on specific terrain — more actionable than general PRs
Competitors Who Do This: Strava segments is their crown jewel

Feature / Task: GAP-based training load (TRIMP adjusted for grade)
User Story / Description: A hilly 6-miler should count for more stress than flat
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Grade-adjusted load more accurately reflects physiological stress
Competitors Who Do This: Stryd does this via power; nobody does it via GAP

Feature / Task: Import temp streams + build personal heat performance curves
User Story / Description: Device-recorded temperature cross-referenced with weather API
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Heat affects performance 10-20% — understanding YOUR heat sensitivity is huge
Competitors Who Do This: Klimat annotates weather; Stryd has air power; CORE measures core temp

Feature / Task: Weather-adjusted training load (heat stress index)
User Story / Description: Weight TRIMP/TSS by heat stress — 90°F easy run = harder physiologically
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Stops runners from thinking they're 'getting slower' in summer
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody does this at the training load level

Feature / Task: Import cadence streams — stride length + form analysis
User Story / Description: Per-second cadence → stride length = pace/cadence. Track cadence drift as fatigue indicator.
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Cadence drift in last miles of long runs is a key fatigue signal
Competitors Who Do This: Garmin running dynamics, Stryd, COROS
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI coach explains form changes contextually

Feature / Task: Running economy tracking — pace at given HR over time
User Story / Description: 7:30/mi at 155bpm today vs 160bpm 3 months ago = real fitness improvement
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Running economy (Efficiency Factor) is more useful than VDOT for day-to-day tracking
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks shows Pa:HR decoupling; Stryd shows running economy
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Trend over time with contextual explanation is unique

Feature / Task: Fatigue resistance metric — last 25% vs first 75%
User Story / Description: Track pace maintenance over run duration, especially in long runs
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Fatigue resistance is the #1 predictor of marathon performance
Competitors Who Do This: Stryd durability metric; WKO5 Stamina
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Tracked over time with coach commentary

Feature / Task: Negative split tendency tracker
User Story / Description: Track positive/negative/even split patterns by workout type
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Pacing strategy is the most fixable error in race execution
Competitors Who Do This: Metathon does basic split analysis
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Coach integration: 'You tend to go out too fast on tempos'

Feature / Task: Time of day analysis — circadian performance profile
User Story / Description: Build personal profile: morning vs evening performance by workout type
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Knowing your best training time optimizes workout scheduling
Competitors Who Do This: Runalyze shows time-of-day distribution

Feature / Task: Training partner effect analysis
User Story / Description: athlete_count shows group vs solo — correlate with pace, RPE, completion
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): 'Your average pace is 15s/mi faster on group runs' is powerful social insight
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody tracks this systematically

Feature / Task: Route familiarity effect — detect repeated routes
User Story / Description: Cluster similar GPS routes, analyze performance on familiar vs new
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Runners perform better on known routes (reduced mental load)
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody does route-performance correlation

Feature / Task: GPS route visualization with pace/HR color overlay
User Story / Description: Interactive map with pace/HR gradient, point-click detail, playback scrub
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Route visualization is expected by every runner
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Garmin, WorkOutDoors all show route maps
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Pace coloring + elevation profile on map

Feature / Task: Segment discovery — find popular segments near your routes
User Story / Description: Show nearby segments on map with your best efforts and improvement trends
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Gamification through segment hunting increases engagement
Competitors Who Do This: Strava Explore, Strava Local Legends

Feature / Task: Workout comparison tool — overlay pace, HR, environmental factors
User Story / Description: Compare this tempo to last 5 tempos with weather/elevation context
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Comparison with context prevents false conclusions about performance
Competitors Who Do This: Intervals.icu has activity comparison; TrainingPeaks has workout comparison
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Automatic environmental normalization in comparison is unique

Feature / Task: Device/watch tracking per activity
User Story / Description: Track which device recorded which activity, identify data quirks by device
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Device-specific HR accuracy varies significantly
Competitors Who Do This: SportTracks tracks device

Feature / Task: Pace curve / Critical Speed model
User Story / Description: Best pace visualization with 42-day vs all-time overlay; Critical Speed calculation
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): CS is a better fitness marker than VDOT for many purposes
Competitors Who Do This: Stryd Critical Power, WKO5 Power Duration Curve

Feature / Task: Enhanced HR zone breakdown per activity
User Story / Description: Compare to target zones for workout type; trend zone distribution over weeks
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Zone compliance tells you if you're actually training at the right intensities
Competitors Who Do This: Strava subscriber zones, Intervals.icu, TrainingPeaks

Feature / Task: Training distribution analysis — shift recommendations
User Story / Description: 'Your Threshold distribution would benefit from more Z1 volume'
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): 80/20 principle: most runners train too hard on easy days
Competitors Who Do This: Runalyze polarization analysis, Intervals.icu distribution
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Actionable recommendation to shift distribution is unique

Feature / Task: Kudos tracking & sync from Strava
User Story / Description: Track who gives you kudos, how often, and engagement patterns
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Social validation drives app engagement and is genuinely fun data
Competitors Who Do This: Strava shows kudos but doesn't analyze patterns
Notes: Rate limit: 1 API call per activity

Feature / Task: Kudos leaderboard + engagement trend analysis
User Story / Description: Rank supporters, identify what activities get most engagement
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Social engagement data drives sharing behavior
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody analyzes kudos patterns

Feature / Task: 'Ghost kudos' detector — friends who went quiet
User Story / Description: Rolling window detection of supporters who stopped engaging
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Fun social insight that creates conversation and re-engagement
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody does this

Feature / Task: Comments tracking from Strava
User Story / Description: Import who commented and what — show highlights on workout detail
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Social context enriches the workout review experience
Competitors Who Do This: Strava shows comments but doesn't aggregate

Feature / Task: Social engagement dashboard — charts, trends, leaderboard
User Story / Description: Kudos trend, engagement rate, top friends, best time to post
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): A completely unique analytics view — nobody does social analytics for runners
Competitors Who Do This: Nothing comparable exists

Feature / Task: Club activity feed analysis
User Story / Description: Show what club members are doing, trends, popular routes
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Club engagement creates community and retention
Competitors Who Do This: Strava Clubs is basic feed

Feature / Task: Strava gear sync — import gear_id + GET /gear/{id}
User Story / Description: Link every workout to specific shoes: name, brand, model, total distance
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Shoe tracking is the foundation for all shoe intelligence features
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Garmin, Runalyze, SportTracks all track gear

Feature / Task: Shoe mileage dashboard with retirement alerts
User Story / Description: Per-shoe mileage by workout type, month, % toward configurable retirement threshold
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Shoe retirement directly affects injury risk — worn shoes = higher impact forces
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Runalyze, ShoeCycle, Garmin

Feature / Task: Shoe efficiency model — controlled comparison across shoes
User Story / Description: After adjusting for pace, HR, temp, elevation, fatigue, grade: which shoe produces best running economy?
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): No app currently isolates shoe performance from confounding variables
Competitors Who Do This: Stryd has basic shoe analytics; nobody controls for all variables
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Flagship feature — THIS IS THE SHOE KILLER APP

Feature / Task: Shoe rotation analysis + patterns
User Story / Description: Auto-detect which shoes for which workout types, visualize rotation
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Shoe rotation extends shoe life and reduces injury risk
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody does rotation analysis

Feature / Task: Shoe recommendation engine — suggest shoe for tomorrow
User Story / Description: Based on workout type, mileage, efficiency data, recent usage
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): 'Wear the Pegasus tomorrow — save the Vaporfly for race day'
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody does this

Feature / Task: Shoe break-in curve — performance vs mileage accumulation
User Story / Description: Track sweet spot (many runners report 50-150mi best) and degradation
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Data-driven shoe retirement instead of arbitrary mileage cutoffs
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody tracks break-in curves

Feature / Task: Injury correlation by shoe
User Story / Description: Cross-reference soreness reports with shoe used and mileage
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Direct connection between equipment and injury risk
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody correlates shoes to injury

Feature / Task: Surface type inference (trail vs road) from GPS+elevation+pace
User Story / Description: Combined with shoe data: performance by shoe × surface type
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Trail miles degrade shoes differently; surface-shoe optimization
Competitors Who Do This: Komoot does surface detection for routing; nobody for training analysis

Feature / Task: Import full activity detail (calories, suffer_score, pr_count, photos)
User Story / Description: Selectively import rich metadata from GET /activities/{id}
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Richer data enables richer analysis and more context for coaching
Competitors Who Do This: All serious integrations use activity detail endpoint

Feature / Task: Import latlng streams (full GPS coordinates)
User Story / Description: Foundation for route visualization, route familiarity, segment matching, surface inference
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): GPS data unlocks an entire class of features
Competitors Who Do This: Every map-based tool ingests GPS

Feature / Task: Import moving streams (boolean per-second)
User Story / Description: Distinguish stopped time from slow pace; identify rest intervals in fartlek
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Accurate moving time is essential for pace accuracy
Competitors Who Do This: Golden Cheetah, Intervals.icu use moving flags

Feature / Task: Historical pattern recognition engine
User Story / Description: Analyze months/years of data: 'You always struggle Day 3 of high mileage weeks', 'You PR when CTL is 50-55 and TSB is +5 to +8'
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Pattern detection is what makes AI coaching actually intelligent vs generic
Competitors Who Do This: WHOOP Journal does basic correlation; nobody does multi-factor pattern detection for running
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: THE core differentiator — an AI coach that actually KNOWS you
Notes: Statistical pattern detection across all stored data

Feature / Task: Predictive insights — forward-looking based on detected patterns
User Story / Description: 'Based on last 6 weeks, you'll PR if you race in next 10 days', 'Your current trajectory suggests 1:25 HM by April'
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Predictions create accountability and excitement — and validate the coaching
Competitors Who Do This: Garmin race predictor is basic; COROS race predictor is basic; nobody predicts training trajectory
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI predictions backed by YOUR data patterns

Feature / Task: Auto-generated weekly insights (3-5 personalized cards)
User Story / Description: Trend alerts, 'what's different this month', surprising correlations
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Proactive insights make the app feel alive vs passive logging
Competitors Who Do This: Garmin Morning Report is closest; Strava subscriber insights are shallow
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Depth and personalization of insights is unique

Feature / Task: Coach memory timeline — what the AI has learned about you
User Story / Description: Visual timeline: 'Learned you struggle in heat (June 2025)', 'Noticed you PR after down weeks'
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Makes AI coaching feel personal and cumulative vs stateless
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody visualizes AI learning about the user

Feature / Task: Automatic insights dashboard — dedicated page
User Story / Description: Weekly insight generation, trend alerts, 3-month rolling comparison
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): A page you come back to every week for your 'training report card'
Competitors Who Do This: Runalyze has some insight features

Feature / Task: Race day countdown & prep (2 weeks before A race)
User Story / Description: Daily tips, race checklist, weather forecast, pace band generator, nutrition reminders, course analysis, fitness prediction
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Pre-race anxiety is real — structured countdown builds confidence
Competitors Who Do This: Garmin has basic race widget; nobody has a 2-week guided prep sequence
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI-powered race prep tailored to YOUR specific race and fitness

Feature / Task: Running streak & consistency tracking
User Story / Description: Streaks, consistency %, perfect weeks — gentle gamification
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Consistency is the #1 factor in running improvement
Competitors Who Do This: SmashRun badges, Nike Run Club streaks
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Tied to AI coaching: 'Great consistency this month'

Feature / Task: Soreness body map — tap body parts, 1-5 scale, track patterns
User Story / Description: Schema exists, UI doesn't. Correlate with shoes, mileage, workout type.
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Early soreness detection prevents injury — the #1 reason runners quit
Competitors Who Do This: WHOOP has pain tracking; Recover Athletics has prehab
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Correlated with shoes + training load is unique

Feature / Task: Wellness trends dashboard — HRV, RHR, sleep, weight, stress
User Story / Description: Visualization of health inputs over time from Apple Health / Intervals.icu
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Understanding inputs is as important as outputs for long-term performance
Competitors Who Do This: Athlytic, WHOOP, Oura all do this for recovery; nobody connects to training
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Wellness trends CONNECTED to training outcomes is unique

Feature / Task: Sentiment-aware coach — dynamic tone adaptation
User Story / Description: If user seems frustrated/anxious, adjust tone. Remember emotional patterns.
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Emotional intelligence separates good coaching from data dumps
Competitors Who Do This: No AI coaching app adapts to emotional state

Feature / Task: Periodization view — Base→Build→Peak→Taper with overlays
User Story / Description: Show training phases, where user is in cycle, what's coming next
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Periodization is the fundamental structure of all training programs
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks ATP view, Intervals.icu season view
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI explains WHY you're in this phase

Feature / Task: Cross-training support — bike/swim/strength with equivalent stress
User Story / Description: Log non-run activities, calculate equivalent training stress
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Hybrid athletes need unified load tracking across modalities
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks, Intervals.icu handle multi-sport; nobody unifies strength+endurance well
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Unified stress model is the biggest whitespace in the market
Notes: Strava sends non-run activities (currently filtered out)

Feature / Task: Running power estimates from pace+grade+bodyweight
User Story / Description: Stryd-like functionality without requiring a power meter
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Power normalizes for hills, wind, and terrain — more objective than pace
Competitors Who Do This: Stryd requires hardware; COROS/Garmin wrist power is noisy
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Accessible running power without additional hardware
Notes: Requires grade_smooth streams and body weight

Feature / Task: Ultra marathon support — 50K to 100M
User Story / Description: Time-based training, elevation as primary metric, aid station planning, power hiking
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Ultra running is the fastest growing segment of running; completely underserved by tech
Competitors Who Do This: Vert.run focuses on trail/ultra; nobody does AI coaching for ultras
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI ultra coaching is a blue ocean

Feature / Task: User preference tracking — persist to DB
User Story / Description: Learn preferred workout times, distance preferences, communication style
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Personalization compounds — the more the AI knows, the better it coaches
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody persists user preferences for coaching context

Feature / Task: Shareable race cards — IG Story/Post/Twitter sizes
User Story / Description: Beautiful cards with finish time, VDOT, course map, splits, weather, branding
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Viral growth loop — users share, friends discover Dreamy
Competitors Who Do This: Strava generates share cards; nobody generates ANALYSIS share cards
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Share cards include AI insights, not just metrics

Feature / Task: Weekly recap card — shareable weekly summary
User Story / Description: Miles, runs, key workout, fitness trend, VDOT change, branding
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Weekly sharing creates habitual engagement
Competitors Who Do This: Strava has weekly summary; Athlytic has daily

Feature / Task: PR celebration cards with confetti + share button
User Story / Description: Confetti animation, old vs new PR comparison, improvement %
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Celebrating wins drives retention and word-of-mouth
Competitors Who Do This: Strava celebrates PRs; nobody generates a share-ready PR card with context
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: PR card includes training journey narrative

Feature / Task: Milestone celebrations — lifetime miles, streaks, race count, VDOT
User Story / Description: Achievement system for non-PR milestones
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Long-term engagement through milestone recognition
Competitors Who Do This: SmashRun badges, Nike Run Club achievements

Feature / Task: Public profile / race resume — getdreamy.run/@username
User Story / Description: Optional public page: race history, PRs, VDOT chart, shoe rotation
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Public profiles create organic discovery and build running identity
Competitors Who Do This: Strava profiles are social; nobody has a 'race resume'

Feature / Task: Route export as GPX/TCX
User Story / Description: Export routes with optional GAP overlay
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Data portability builds trust; useful for sharing courses
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Garmin export routes
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: GAP overlay on exported route is unique

Feature / Task: Weekly email digest (or in-app digest card)
User Story / Description: Miles, key workouts, trends, next week preview — delivered weekly
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Re-engagement channel for users who drift away from daily use
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks weekly email, Strava weekly summary

Feature / Task: Apple Health integration — sleep, HRV, RHR, weight
User Story / Description: Import health data for wellness trends and post-run analysis
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Apple Health is the #1 health data aggregator on iOS
Competitors Who Do This: Athlytic, HRV4Training, many apps read Apple Health

Feature / Task: Garmin Connect integration (alternative to Strava)
User Story / Description: Direct Garmin import: activities, HR, sleep, HRV, Body Battery, stress
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Garmin has 30%+ of the GPS watch market — not everyone uses Strava
Competitors Who Do This: Most analytics tools connect to Garmin

Feature / Task: Push notifications — workout reminders, check-ins, PRs, race countdown
User Story / Description: Service worker push for proactive coaching moments
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Notifications drive habit formation and re-engagement
Competitors Who Do This: Nearly all mobile apps have push

Feature / Task: Full data export — CSV/JSON of all user data
User Story / Description: All workouts, race results, plans, conversations, assessments, shoes
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Data ownership builds trust; GDPR compliance
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Garmin offer bulk export

Feature / Task: API for third-party apps
User Story / Description: REST API for accessing Dreamy data externally
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Creates developer ecosystem — other tools build on Dreamy
Competitors Who Do This: Strava, Intervals.icu, TrainingPeaks have APIs

Feature / Task: Transparent training load dashboard — show the math
User Story / Description: Display CTL/ATL/TSB with customizable time constants, visible formulas, adjustable TRIMP models
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Black-box scores destroy trust. Transparent models build expert users who evangelize.
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks (TSS/PMC), Intervals.icu (customizable), Runalyze (TRIMP), Elevate (free CTL/ATL/TSB)
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Show the math AND explain it in plain English — nobody does both
Notes: Biggest whitespace per all 3 research sources

Feature / Task: Auto-detected threshold from workout data (no lab test needed)
User Story / Description: Estimate lactate threshold from workout HR/pace data patterns — DFA alpha-1 or heart rate deflection
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Lactate threshold is the most important training anchor. Lab tests cost $200+ and require clinic visits.
Competitors Who Do This: AI Endurance (DFA alpha-1), Garmin (HR deflection), COROS (HR-pace relationship), Xert (automatic FTP)
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Auto-detect AND explain to user why threshold changed
Notes: AI Endurance pioneered this; massive differentiator

Feature / Task: Personalized recovery model — learns YOUR physiology
User Story / Description: Track how YOUR body responds to different training loads, not population averages
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Individual recovery rates vary 3-5x between athletes. Population models are wildly wrong for edge cases.
Competitors Who Do This: AI Endurance (unique: learns individual response), WHOOP (partially personalized), Morpheus (recovery-shifted zones)
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Recovery model that improves over months of data
Notes: Requires 6-8 weeks of data to calibrate

Feature / Task: Lifestyle-performance correlation engine
User Story / Description: 'Your tempo pace improves 2% when you sleep 8+ hours', 'Alcohol night before correlates with 15s/mi slower easy runs'
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Connecting lifestyle inputs to training outputs is THE most asked coaching question
Competitors Who Do This: WHOOP Journal does basic correlation; nobody connects lifestyle to running-specific outcomes

Feature / Task: Aerobic decoupling tracking (Pa:HR drift)
User Story / Description: Track cardiac drift in second half of easy/long runs as aerobic fitness indicator
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Decoupling >5% = aerobic base not big enough — actionable coaching signal
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks (Pw:HR), Intervals.icu (decoupling analysis), WKO5
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Plain English explanation: 'Your heart worked 8% harder in the second half — more easy miles needed'

Feature / Task: Interval auto-detection + scoring
User Story / Description: Algorithmically detect intervals without lap button, then score consistency/recovery/target accuracy
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Most runners forget to press lap; interval quality data gets lost
Competitors Who Do This: Intervals.icu is the gold standard here; nobody else does it well
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI scores intervals AND feeds back into plan adjustment

Feature / Task: Heat acclimation protocol tracking
User Story / Description: Track cumulative heat exposure and adaptation progress over 10-14 day protocol
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Heat acclimation (plasma volume expansion) is the single biggest legal performance enhancer for summer racing
Competitors Who Do This: Garmin has heat acclimation status; CORE sensor measures core temp
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Guided protocol with progress tracking is unique

Feature / Task: Altitude adjustment for pace/performance
User Story / Description: Normalize performances across different elevations; predict sea-level equivalents
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): A 20:00 5K at 6000ft ≈ 19:15 at sea level — context matters hugely
Competitors Who Do This: V.O2 has altitude conversion, Runalyze has corrections
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Automatic adjustment based on GPS elevation data

Feature / Task: Race execution analysis + replay
User Story / Description: Deep split analysis: pacing strategy grade, comparison to plan, environmental factors, what-if scenarios
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): The #1 post-race question: 'What happened and what should I do differently?'
Competitors Who Do This: Metathon does basic marathon analysis; Strava shows splits but no grading
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI grades your race execution and suggests specific pacing changes for next race

Feature / Task: AI chat coach with FULL training context awareness
User Story / Description: Ask questions, get answers that reference YOUR actual data, history, patterns, and upcoming plan
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): The ultimate differentiator: AI coaching that's as informed as a human coach who's reviewed your entire training log
Competitors Who Do This: No tool has an AI coach that actually knows your full data history
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: DREAMY'S CORE VALUE PROPOSITION — this is WHY users choose Dreamy over everything else
Notes: Already partially built; this is about deepening context

Feature / Task: Recovery-adjusted training zones (shift daily based on readiness)
User Story / Description: HR zones shift based on recovery status — your Zone 2 ceiling is lower when fatigued
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Static zones assume you're always fresh. Daily zone adjustment prevents overtraining.
Competitors Who Do This: Morpheus (unique: daily shifting zones based on HRV recovery)
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Dynamic zones with explanation: 'Zone 2 ceiling lowered today because HRV is down 12%'

Feature / Task: Real-time form degradation detection during runs/races
User Story / Description: Track cadence drop, GCT increase, stride length shortening as fatigue proxy during the run
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Form breakdown is the first sign of pacing problems — catching it early saves races
Competitors Who Do This: Garmin shows running dynamics but doesn't flag degradation; Stryd shows form changes
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI explanation: 'Your cadence dropped 6% at mile 18 — this pattern preceded your wall at mile 22 last time'

Feature / Task: Training plan adapts to BOTH biometrics AND life context
User Story / Description: Integrate calendar (busy week), travel (altitude/timezone), sleep quality, social context into plan adjustments
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Most adaptive plans react only to workout data. Real coaching considers the whole person.
Competitors Who Do This: 2PEAK uses time-budget; nobody integrates life context
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: The most holistic adaptive planning in the market

Feature / Task: Race fueling calculator
User Story / Description: Calculate carb/fluid requirements based on pace, duration, weather, body weight for a specific race
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Bonking (glycogen depletion) is the most common race failure mode — avoidable with proper fueling
Competitors Who Do This: Precision Hydration (sweat test), MyMottiv (nutrition calculator), EatMyRide
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Personalized fueling plan for YOUR race, not generic guidelines

Feature / Task: Unified strength + endurance load quantification
User Story / Description: A heavy squat session should contribute to fatigue score so run plan adjusts tomorrow
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): The 'strength-endurance bridge' is the #1 whitespace identified across all research sources
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks handles multi-sport but not gym; Wahoo SYSTM includes yoga/strength but cycling-focused
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Single systemic stress score combining running and strength — nobody does this well
Notes: Huge opportunity for hybrid athletes (Hyrox, CrossFit Endurance)

Feature / Task: File fidelity validation + source-of-truth selection
User Story / Description: Detect when Strava-imported files lose power/laps; prefer Garmin originals; warn about data gaps
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Silent data corruption undermines all downstream analytics
Competitors Who Do This: Intervals.icu explicitly warns about Strava API constraints; nobody else surfaces data quality
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Transparency about data quality builds trust with data-savvy users

Feature / Task: Coach-athlete platform — manage athletes, shared calendar, chat
User Story / Description: Multi-athlete management with AI doing analytical grunt work, human coach adds wisdom
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Coach platform creates B2B revenue stream and network effects
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks (dominant), Final Surge (free tier), Intervals.icu (coach features)
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI handles analysis, human handles relationship — best of both worlds

Feature / Task: Custom alerts/rules engine
User Story / Description: Alerts when training load exceeds threshold, HRV drops below baseline, ramp rate too high
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Proactive alerts prevent injury and overtraining — the most valuable coaching intervention
Competitors Who Do This: Intervals.icu has some alerting; myTrainingForecast does injury risk alerts
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI-contextualized alerts: not just 'load is high' but 'load is high AND you slept poorly — consider skipping today'

Feature / Task: Training block summary — end-of-block report card
User Story / Description: At end of a training block: what adaptations occurred, compliance %, key improvements, areas for growth
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Periodic reflection drives learning and motivation
Competitors Who Do This: Nobody generates block-level summaries automatically
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: AI-written narrative of your training block story

Feature / Task: 'Data gap detector' with fallback load logic
User Story / Description: If a run is missing HR or power, still maintain coherent load history using fallback models
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Missing data shouldn't create holes in longitudinal analytics
Competitors Who Do This: Polar handles missing sensors gracefully

Feature / Task: 'Explain the model' UI per metric — inputs, constants, time windows
User Story / Description: For every metric, a expandable section showing exactly how it's calculated
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Transparency is the antidote to black-box fatigue — and a trust moat
Competitors Who Do This: Runalyze documents formulas in help docs; nobody shows math inline
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Click any metric → see the formula → builds expert users who trust and evangelize

Feature / Task: Plan compliance score — intent-aware, not just completion
User Story / Description: Did you execute the POINT of the week? Not just 'did you run 5 days'
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Intensity compliance matters more than volume compliance
Competitors Who Do This: TrainingPeaks has compliance coloring; Intervals.icu has fuzzy matching
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Intent-aware: 'You hit 100% of mileage but missed all tempo targets'

Feature / Task: Menstrual cycle-adjusted training recommendations
User Story / Description: Adjust readiness, training intensity, and recovery expectations by cycle phase
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Female athletes are systematically underserved by training apps that ignore hormonal variation
Competitors Who Do This: Wild.ai, FitrWoman — but no mainstream running app does this
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Mainstream integration of female physiology — not a separate 'women's app'

Feature / Task: Morning readiness score — HRV + sleep + subjective feel
User Story / Description: Morning check-in that combines objective metrics with subjective feel
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): The moment of highest coaching value: 'Should I train hard today?'
Competitors Who Do This: WHOOP recovery, Oura readiness, HRV4Training morning readiness, Garmin Training Readiness
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Transparent model (not black box) with training-specific recommendation

Feature / Task: Community benchmarks — anonymous comparison to similar runners
User Story / Description: See how your training metrics compare to runners with similar goals/experience
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Context makes metrics meaningful: 'Your VDOT is in the 75th percentile for first-time marathoners'
Competitors Who Do This: Strava does age/weight comparison on segments; nobody does training metric benchmarking
Notes: Requires user base to be meaningful

Feature / Task: Baseline calibration flow — guided assessment run
User Story / Description: Guide new users through a calibration run to initialize VDOT, threshold, and zones accurately
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Better initial data → better models → better coaching from Day 1
Competitors Who Do This: COROS EvoLab requires 25-min uninterrupted run to unlock; nobody makes it a guided experience
Dreamy Differentiation Angle: Onboarding experience that doubles as first coaching moment

Feature / Task: Intervals.icu deep integration — two-way sync
User Story / Description: Import wellness data, export planned workouts, sync analysis
Why It Matters (Sports Science / UX): Intervals.icu is the power user's platform — integrating captures data-nerd segment
Competitors Who Do This: Intervals.icu has open API + wellness writes + API cookbook
